headline: Nvidia explores $500 million investment in UK self-driving startup Wayve
summary: STORY: U.S. chip giant Nvidia could invest $500 million in Britain's Wayve.That's according to the autonomous driving tech group on Thursday.They said Nvidia signed a letter of intent for the possible investment in the next funding round.It comes after Britain and the U.S. signed a technology pact aimed at boosting ties in AI and other fields.Wayve was founded in 2017 and raised more than $1 billion last year.Its autonomous driving platforms have been powered by a partnership with Nvidia, whose chips are now a major part of a global AI boom.Japan's Softbank and ride-hailing platform Uber also made a separate investment in the firm last year.Wayve's technology uses machine learning with camera sensors mounted on the vehicles to learn from traffic patterns and driver behavior.That's different to conventional systems that rely on detailed digital maps and coding.Wayve currently operates in Britain and the U.S. and expanded testing and development to wider markets like Germany and Japan.Nvidia also pledged $2.70 billion in investments in the British AI startup ecosystem on Thursday.

raw.headline: Nvidia explores $500 million investment in UK self-driving startup Wayve
raw.summary: STORY: U.S. chip giant Nvidia could invest $500 million in Britain's Wayve.That's according to the autonomous driving tech group on Thursday.They said Nvidia signed a letter of intent for the possible investment in the next funding round.It comes after Britain and the U.S. signed a technology pact aimed at boosting ties in AI and other fields.Wayve was founded in 2017 and raised more than $1 billion last year.Its autonomous driving platforms have been powered by a partnership with Nvidia, whose chips are now a major part of a global AI boom.Japan's Softbank and ride-hailing platform Uber also made a separate investment in the firm last year.Wayve's technology uses machine learning with camera sensors mounted on the vehicles to learn from traffic patterns and driver behavior.That's different to conventional systems that rely on detailed digital maps and coding.Wayve currently operates in Britain and the U.S. and expanded testing and development to wider markets like Germany and Japan.Nvidia also pledged $2.70 billion in investments in the British AI startup ecosystem on Thursday.

headline: Uber, Flytrex partner to launch drone delivery
summary: Uber (UBER) and Flytrex announced a strategic partnership and Uber’s first investment in drone delivery, marking a major step forward in the future of autonomous logistics. Expected to begin with Uber Eats pilot markets in the U.S. by the end of the year, the new service combines Flytrex’s autonomous drone delivery system with Uber’s global platform and logistics expertise, creating a fully integrated end-to-end experience. headline: 'Against The Principles Of The Fourth Amendment' 80,000 AI Cameras Track Americans Daily As CEO Claims He Can Eliminate All Crime In 10 Years
summary: A 38-year-old CEO with no prior experience in police technology is taking on one of America’s most powerful law enforcement companies. Garrett Langley, founder of surveillance company Flock Safety, previously partnered with Axon Enterprise (NASDAQ:AXON) before the relationship ended earlier this year over pricing and competition concerns, Forbes reported. The Atlanta-based entrepreneur now oversees more than 80,000 AI-powered cameras across 49 states, helping solve an estimated 1 million crimes

headline: Mark Cuban Says 'Everything Is a Meme' in Today's Market — and Warns Retail Traders Can 'Move Stocks More Than Analysts' Opendoor Is A Good Example
summary: Mark Cuban says “everything is a meme” in today’s stock market, a blunt assessment of how retail traders have reshaped investing. Cuban contrasted the current environment with the dot-com bubble in a recent conversation with Axios, arguing that younger investors now treat stocks much like meme coins and cryptocurrencies as vehicles for speculation. The rise of retail trading, powered by social media and easy-to-use apps, has moved market dynamics in ways Wall Street analysts can’t always predict
